greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Array read by ascending antidiagonals: A(n,k) = A099563(A265609(n,k)), with n as row >= 0, k as column >= 0; the most significant digit in the factorial base representation of rising factorial n^(k) = (n+k-1)!/(n-1)!.
comment: Square array A(row,col) is read by ascending antidiagonals as: A(0,0), A(1,0), A(0,1), A(2,0), A(1,1), A(0,2), A(3,0), A(2,1), A(1,2), A(0,3), ...
A265609(n,k) is the rising factorial, also known as Pochhammer symbol and A099563(n) is the most significant "digit" (place holder) in the factorial representation (A007623) of n.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..7259; the first 120 antidiagonals of array
Index entries for sequences related to factorial base representation
example: The top left corner of the array A265609 with its terms shown in factorial base (A007623) looks like this:
Taking the most significant "digit" (placeholder that may get arbitrarily large values) gives us the top left corner of this array:
program: (define (A265890bi row col) (A099563 (A265609bi row col))) ;; Code for A265609bi given in A265609.
xref: Row 0: A000007, rows 1 & 2: A000012, row 3: A008619 (see comment in A001710).
Main diagonal: A265891 (essentially, without the initial 1 from the corner of this array).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Dec 19 2015
